When is done done? I was recently at the New Theatre Oxford to see the Welsh National Opera Cenedlaethol Cymru production of Bernstein‚Äôs operetta Candide. Stuffed with great tunes and witty lyrics, it has one of the best overtures and most powerful closing numbers of any show I know, and is one of my favourites. üíéüêùüè≥Ô∏èüåà Although its popularity has increased since its disappointing Broadway debut in 1956, it‚Äôs widely regarded as a show that‚Äôs never reached its potential. Reworked many times over the years, this production was based on a version created by Lonny Price for the New York Philharmonic (trivia fans will enjoy the fact that Price was Neil in the movie Dirty Dancing, which coincidentally was the next show to play at the New). I think it‚Äôs the strongest version, but I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if someone else had a try at fixing it in the future. Will it ever be considered finished? Who gets to decide? ü§∑üèª‚ôÇÔ∏è That should never be the case at work. When you give or are given a task, are the completion criteria clear to all parties? Do you have a shared definition of done with your team for regular tasks? Having a definition of ‚Äúdone‚Äù is vital for effective teamwork and delegation. It‚Äôs something we can all use across our business but, unlike opinions of Candide, its criteria must be objective!

There‚Äôs a trend in modern opera of operatic adaptations of serious, contemporary, books and movies. Heavy, weighty things converted into opera form. Operas like: Dead Man Walking Of Mice and Men The Shining The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale Bel Canto Breaking the Waves Cold Mountain Il Postino The Exterminating Angel There are a lot of them. But light, funny, silly films and books never seem to get the same treatment. That‚Äôs where you come in. Pitch us an operatic adaptation of a non-heavy, non-deadly-serious book. BUT (here‚Äôs the catch) DO give it a heavy, deadly-serious TITLE. So maybe your proposed operatic adaptation of Happy Gilmore would be titled ‚ÄúGilmore: 18 Holes and a Search for Meaning‚Äù Or your proposed operatic adaptation of Step Brothers would be titled ‚ÄúThe Bonds of Brotherhood‚Äù You can share your proposed serious opera title and the silly, light source you are adapting in the comments to this post.

When the Sydney Opera House was commissioned, the overall objective was to create "the best opera house that can be built." While it's stunning design completely met the brief, the acoustics did not. The actor John Malkovich said they "would do an aeroplane hanger a disservice" During the course of the project, style overtook substance. The original objective was not regularly reviewed and the purpose of the project got lost. Read our blog post on what went wrong with our tips on how to getting setting objectives and holding reviews right. #settinggoals #objectives #performancereviews #performancemanagement https://bit.ly/3P3MH0b

How do you practice? Do you even think about practice? I am regularly reminding my clients to step out of the dance of daily ‚Äúdoing‚Äù and move up to the balcony for some work on their business. On my visit to the Paris Opera with Edilia G√§nz, Oliver Radtke, and Aparna Bhasin, we visited the practice room where dancers could practice on the same angled floor they would experience on the stage (The Paris Opera stage as a 5% grade). I was convicted. Usually I ask my clients to step off the stage to observe. I usually don‚Äôt ask them to step off the stage to practice. And then there was this practice room. Its beauty and attention to detail elevated the idea of practice. It was more beautiful and approachable than the actual stage and made me think that perhaps practice might be more important than the performance itself. So, here is my question: What new skill, behavior, or mindset are you currently practicing? Are you giving it a Paris Opera Rehearsal Room level of importance? #practice, #leadership, #parisopera, #adaptiveleadership
